case_name: widow of Mrityunjoy Mullick v. infant son of Mrityunjoy Mullick

facts.text: This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of the Calcutta High Court dated 1950-05-19.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of the Calcutta High Court, dated the 19th May, 1950, which affirmed the judgment of a single Judge of the Original Side of that Court passed on 9th February, 1949, in Suit No. 2481 of 1947.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court appellate judgment affirmed the judgment of a single Judge of the Original Side dated 1949-02-09 in Suit No. 2481 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: which affirmed the judgment of a single Judge of the Original Side of that Court passed on 9th February, 1949, in Suit No. 2481 of 1947. The plaintiff, who is the appellant before us, is the widow of one Mrityunjoy Mullick, a wealthy Hindu resident of Calcutta, while the defendant, who is still an infant, is the only son of Mrityunjoy born of his first wife Kiranbala, who died during the lifetime of her husband.

facts.text: Plaintiff is the widow of Mrityunjoy Mullick, a wealthy Hindu resident of Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, who is the appellant before us, is the widow of one Mrityunjoy Mullick, a wealthy Hindu resident of Calcutta, while the defendant, who is still an infant, is the only son of Mrityunjoy born of his first wife Kiranbala, who died during the lifetime of her husband.

facts.text: Defendant is the only son of Mrityunjoy born of his first wife Kiranbala, who died during the lifetime of her husband, and is still an infant.

anchor.surface_text: while the defendant, who is still an infant, is the only son of Mrityunjoy born of his first wife Kiranbala, who died during the lifetime of her husband. The controversy between the parties centers round the short point as to whether the plaintiff is entitled, after the death of her husband, to act as shebait of an idol named Sree Sree Nitto Gopal Jew founded by Mrityunjoy and his mother, either solely or jointly with the defendant, her step-son.

facts.text: Idol named Sree Sree Nitto Gopal Jew founded by Mrityunjoy and his mother.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy between the parties centers round the short point as to whether the plaintiff is entitled, after the death of her husband, to act as shebait of an idol named Sree Sree Nitto Gopal Jew founded by Mrityunjoy and his mother, either solely or jointly with the defendant, her step-son.

facts.text: Neither side adduced any evidence before the trial judge; questions argued as questions of law on construction of indenture and Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937 as amended 1938.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that neither side adduced any evidence before the trial judge during the hearing of the case and the questions raised in the suit were argued as questions of law turning on the construction of the indenture which created the endowment as well as of the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act  Act XVIII of 1937 as amended by Act XI of 1938 .

facts.text: Dhananjoy Mullick, adoptive father of Mrityunjoy, died on 1907-08-28 leaving widow Nitto Sundari and adopted son Mrityunjoy who was then a minor.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that one Dhananjoy Mullick, who was the adoptive father of Mrityunjoy, died on 28th of August, 1907, leaving behind him, his widow Nitto Sundari and the adopted son Mrityunjoy, who was then a minor.

facts.text: Nitto Sundari obtained letters of administration to the estate of Dhananjoy on 1910-02-11 limited during minority of adopted son.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1910, Nitto Sundari obtained letters of administration to the estate of the deceased Dhananjoy limited during the minority of the adopted son.

facts.text: On 1920-06-13, Nitto Sundari purchased house property No. 14, Syakrapara Lane out of monies of Dhananjoy's estate.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1920, the widow purchased a house property in the city of Calcutta - being premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane - out of the monies belonging to the estate of her husband,

facts.text: On 1934-10-10, Nitto Sundari conveyed premises No. 14 Syakrapara Lane to Mrityunjoy who had attained majority.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 10, 1934, she conveyed the said property to Mrityunjoy who had by that time attained majority.

facts.text: On 1934-10-10, Nitto Sundari and Mrityunjoy executed indenture dedicating properties in Schedules A and B including No. 14 Syakrapara Lane to deity Nitto Gopal Jew.

anchor.surface_text: On the very same day that this property was conveyed to Mrityunjoy, Nitto Sundari and Mrityunjoy together executed an indenture, by which certain properties described in Schedules A and B of the document and including premises No. 14 Syakrapara Lane, were dedicated to deity Nitto Gopal Jew.

facts.text: Indentures recites Nitto Sundari established and consecrated idol in premises No. 14 Syakrapara Lane with consent of son and performed worship.

anchor.surface_text: The indenture recites that Nitto Sundari had, with the consent and concurrence of her son, established and consecrated the said idol and located it in premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane, and that she had been performing the worship and periodical festivals of the deity according to Hindu rites.

facts.text: Nitto Sundari acted as shebait till her death in 1938; after her death Mrityunjoy became shebait.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that Nitto Sundari acted as shebait till her death in 1938 and that after her death Mrityunjoy became the shebait.

facts.text: Kiranbala, first wife of Mrityunjoy, died on 1942-01-14 leaving infant son Debabrata, the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Kiranbala, the first wife of Mrityunjoy, who is referred to in the indenture as stated above, died on 14th January, 1942, leaving her infant son Debabrata, who is the defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Soon after Kiranbala's death, Mrityunjoy married plaintiff Angurbala as second wife.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after her death, Mrityunjoy married the plaintiff Angurbala as his second wife

facts.text: Mrityunjoy died on 1942-07-04 within five months after marriage to Angurbala.

anchor.surface_text: and within five months after this marriage Mrityunjoy died on the 4th of July, 1942.

facts.text: Present suit filed by Angurbala on 1947-08-29 in Original Side Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit was filed in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court on 29th August, 1947, by Angurbala

facts.text: Plaintiff prayed for declaration of sole or joint shebaitship with defendant under indenture or Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, and right of residence in No. 14 Syakrapara Lane.

anchor.surface_text: and she prayed for a declaration that she was the sole shebait of the deity under the terms of the indenture or, in the alternative, was entitled to shebaitship jointly with the defendant, she being a co-heir of her stepson under the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act. There was a further prayer claiming a right of residence in premises No. 14, Syakrapara Lane.

facts.text: Defendant's written statement denied plaintiff's shebait right solely or jointly, asserted defendant sole shebait under deed and law, denied residence right.

anchor.surface_text: The written statement that was filed on behalf of the defendant denied the plaintiffs claim of shebaiti right, either exclusively in herself or jointly with the defendant, and asserted that the defendant was the sole shebait under the terms of the deed of endowment as well as under law. The defendant also contended that the plaintiff was not entitled to any, right of residence in the premises mentioned above.

facts.text: Trial Judge on 1949-02-09 held plaintiff neither sole nor joint shebait, Act inapplicable to shebaitship, not natural guardian; but entitled to residence right.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge by his judgment dated 9th of February, 1949, held that the plaintiff was neither the sole shebait of the deity nor was she entitled to claim shebaiti rights jointly with the defendant and that the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act was inapplicable to devolution of shebaiti rights at all.

facts.text: Plaintiff's appeal to Calcutta High Court heard by Sir Trevor Harries C.J. and Sinha J.; only joint shebaitship pressed; rejected citing Federal Court Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the plaintiff preferred an appeal which came up for hearing before an appeal Bench of the Calcutta High Court consisting of Sir Trevor Harries C.J. and Sinha J. ... The appeal was thus dismissed

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained certificate under article 133(1)(c) of Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff having obtained a certificate under article 133 1  c  of the Constitution has come up in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held plaintiff entitled to joint shebaitship with defendant; set aside lower courts except residence right.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that, in our opinion, the appeal succeeds. The judgment and decree of both the courts below are set aside except the declaration of the right of residence of the plaintiff which was given by the trial court and not disturbed in appeal.

facts.text: Indentures provides 25% net income of debutter property as remuneration for shebait.

anchor.surface_text: A remuneration of 25 per cent. of the net income of the debutter property has also been provided for the shebait or shebaits for the time being.

facts.text: Indentures appoints Nitto Sundari shebait for life, then Mrityunjoy, then wife Kiranbala, then heirs of Mrityunjoy; proviso for appointment if no issue.

anchor.surface_text: That the said Sm. Nitto Sundari Dassi doth hereby constitute and appoint herself the shebait of the said Thakur for the during the term of her natural life and doth hereby declare that after her death her son the said Mrityunjoy Mullick shall become the shebait ... Provided however that in case the said Mrityunjoy Mullick shall happen to die without any issue ...

facts.text: Mrityunjoy died with issue (son Debabrata).

anchor.surface_text: As Mrityunjoy actually left a son, the contingency contemplated by the proviso did not arise at all
certificate under article 133 1 c of the Constitution has come up in appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: We will first advert to and examine the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act and see whether the Act includes within its scope a property of such character as shebaitship is. The exact legal position of a shebait may not be capable

issues.text: whether the words heirs of the said Mrityunjoy occurring in the deed are to be construed not as words of devolution but of direct gift to the heirs under the deed

anchor.surface_text: the words heirs of the said Mrityunjoy occurring in the deed are to be construed not as words of devolution but of direct gift to the heirs under the deed and consequently the expression heirs must mean those who could legally claim as heirs

issues.text: whether reading the clauses as a whole, it would be clear that the intention of the executants of the deed was that the issue of Mrityunjoy would succeed to him as shebaits in the first instance and that no other heir of Mrityunjoy basing his claim either upon general law or any special enactment would be entitled to become shebait so long as any issue of Mrityunjoy was alive

anchor.surface_text: The other contention put forward by the learned counsel turns upon the construction of the relevant clause in the indenture referred to above which lay down the mode of devolution of the shebaitship, and his argument was that reading the clauses as a whole, it would be clear that the intention of the executants of the deed was that the issue of Mrityunjoy would succeed to him as shebaits in the first instance

issues.text: whether succession to shebaitship was not in any way altered or affected by the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges rejected this contention of the appellant primarily on the ground that the identical point was raised and considered by the Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1 and it was held there that succession to shebaitship was not in any way altered or affected by the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act.

arguments.claim: Under the indenture, shebaitship devolves to heirs of Mrityunjoy after Kiranbala, who predeceased him, and under HWRTPA, widow shares equally with son as heir.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial contention raised by Mr. Tek Chand, who appeared on behalf of the plaintiff-appellant, is that under the clause in the indenture relating to devolution of shebaitship, the shebaitship is to go to Kiranbala after the death of Mrityunjoy and after her death it is to vest in the heirs of Mrityunjoy.

arguments.court_reasoning: Indentures specifies heirs after Kiranbala; HWRTPA modifies inheritance to include widow equally; contingency in proviso did not arise.

arguments.claim: Even if 'property' in HWRTPA excludes shebaitship expressly, succession to shebaitship follows ordinary Hindu inheritance rules, altered by HWRTPA.

holdings.text: The plaintiff is entitled to joint shebaitship with the defendant in respect of the debuttar created by the indenture of October 10, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that, in our opinion, the appeal succeeds. The judgment and decree of both the courts below are set aside except the declaration of the right of residence of the plaintiff which was given by the trial court and not disturbed in appeal. In addition to that, it will be declared that the plaintiff is entitled to joint shebaitship with the defendant in respect of the debuttar created by the indenture of October 10, 1934.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indentures directs shebaitship to heirs of Mrityunjoy after Kiranbala who predeceased; HWRTPA entitles widow to same share as son in intestate property including shebaitship; proviso contingency of no issue did not arise.

holdings.text: There is nothing in any of the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights Property Act which excludes from the scope of operation of the Act succession to shebaitship as a recognized form of property in Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that there is nothing in any of the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights Property Act which excludes from the scope of operation of the Act succession to shebaitship is a recognized form of property in Hindu Law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shebaitship is heritable property with beneficial interest; s3 applies to 'any property'; s2 overrides contrary Hindu law; s3(3) and s5 do not limit to testamentable secular property; preamble neutral.

holdings.text: Succession to shebaitship follows the ordinary rules of inheritance under Hindu law unless the founder provides otherwise, and is altered by HWRTPA.

anchor.surface_text: The exact legal position of a shebait may not be capable of precise definition but its implications are fairly well established. It is settled by the pronouncement of the Judicial Committee in Vidya Varuti v. Balusami 48 I.A. 302... shebaitship like any other species of heritable property follows the line of inheritance from the founder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent establishes shebaitship as hybrid office-property, heritable per Hindu succession; Act amends general inheritance law applicable thereto.

holdings.text: The words 'heirs of the said Mrityunjoy' in the indenture are words of devolution, not of direct gift.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that we are not at all impressed by the argument of the learned counsel that the words heirs of the said Mrityunjoy occurring in the document are to be construed as words not of inheritance but of grant. Such construction would be against the language and the whole tenor of the document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with founder retaining ownership and directing lineal devolution; precedent in Umayal Achi supports words of devolution.

holdings.text: The proviso in the indenture applies only to contingency of Mrityunjoy dying without issue and without authority to wife to adopt; heirs unrestricted otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: A proviso is normally an excepting or a qualifying clause and the effect of it is to except out of the preceding clause upon which it is engrafted something which but for the proviso would be within it... As Mrityunjoy actually left a son, the contingency contemplated by the proviso did not arise at all

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: main clause general devolution to heirs; proviso carves exception for power of appointment in no-issue case; contingency absent.

holdings.text: Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi distinguished; inapplicable as trusts there lacked beneficial interest unlike shebaitship.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may not be made to the decision Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1... It seems to us that, properly construed, this decision does not stand in the way of the appellant... we have no materials to hold that in regard to the trusts... the trustees had any beneficial or personal interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts differ: no beneficial interest in Umayal trusts; shebaitship has proprietary element; obiter in Umayal not binding.

holdings.text: Language of indenture does not give wife priority over other heirs; 'Kiranbala' specific, not generic 'wife'.

anchor.surface_text: A point was also raised by Mr. Tek Chand - though it was not pressed seriously - that the language of the indenture would go to suggest that in the matter of succession to shebaitship the wife of Mrityunjoy would have priority over other heirs. It is true that the document speaks only of Kiranbala,... manifestly untenable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document names specific wife Kiranbala; no indication of generic intent.

holdings.text: Plaintiff's right of residence upheld as per trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment and decree of both the courts below are set aside except the declaration of the right of residence of the plaintiff which was given by the trial court and not disturbed in appeal.

holdings.text: Shebaitship is res extra commercium; inalienable by male or female heir.

anchor.surface_text: It is res extra commercium. A male heir cannot alienate it any more than a female heir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent in nature of shebaitship office.

precedents.citation: Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: the Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1 and it was held there that succession to shebaitship was not in any way altered or affected by the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act. The appeal was thus dismissed and the plaintiff having obtained a certificate under article 133 (1) (c) of the Constitution has come up in appeal to this Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: succession to shebaitship was not in any way altered or affected by the provisions of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act
precedents.cited_holding: Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act does not alter succession to shebaitship

precedents.citation: Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: the pronouncement of the Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1. The other contention put forward by the learned counsel turns upon the construction of the relevant clause in the indenture referred to above which lay down the mode of devolution of the shebaitship, and his argument was that reading the clauses as a whole, it would be clear that the intention of the executants of the deed was that the issue of Mrityunjoy would succeed to him as shebaits in the first instance and that no other heir of Mrityunjoy basing his claim either upon general law or any special enactment would be entitled to become shebait so long as any issue of Mrityunjoy was alive.

precedents.cited_proposition: pronouncement on Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act not affecting shebaitship

anchor.surface_text: It is settled by the pronouncement of the Judicial Committee in Vidya Varuti v. Balusami 48 I.A. 302 that the relation of a shebait in regard to debutter property is not that of a trustee to trust property under the English law. In English law the legal estate in the trust property vests in the trustee who holds it for the benefit of cestui que trust. In a Hindu religious endowment on the other hand the entire ownership of the dedicated property is transferred to the deity or the institution itself as a juristic person and the shebait or mahant is a mere manager.

precedents.cited_proposition: relation of a shebait in regard to debutter property is not that of a trustee to trust property under the English law
precedents.cited_holding: Shebait is manager, not trustee; property vests in deity

precedents.citation: Manohar Mukherji v. Bhupendra Nath Mukherji I.L.R. 60 Cal. 452

anchor.surface_text: This was elaborately discussed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court in Manohar Mukherji v. Bhupendra Nath Mukherji I.L.R. 60 Cal. 452 and this decision of the Full Bench was approved of by the Judicial Committee in Ganesh Chunder Dhur v. Lal Behary 63 I.A. 448 and again in Bhabatarini v. Ashalata 70 I.A. 57. The effect of the first two decisions, as the Privy Council pointed out in the last case, was to emphasize the proprietary element in the shebaiti right, and to show that though in some respects anomalous, it was an anomaly to be accepted as having been admitted into Hindu law from an early date.

precedents.case_name: Manohar Mukherji v. Bhupendra Nath Mukherji
precedents.cited_proposition: elaborately discussed proprietary nature of shebaitship
precedents.cited_holding: Shebaitship has character of proprietary right

precedents.citation: Ganesh Chunder Dhur v. Lal Behary 63 I.A. 448

anchor.surface_text: and this decision of the Full Bench was approved of by the Judicial Committee in Ganesh Chunder Dhur v. Lal Behary 63 I.A. 448 and again in Bhabatarini v. Ashalata 70 I.A. 57. The effect of the first two decisions, as the Privy Council pointed out in the last case, was to emphasize the proprietary element in the shebaiti right, and to show that though in some respects anomalous, it was an anomaly to be accepted as having been admitted into Hindu law from an early date.

precedents.case_name: Ganesh Chunder Dhur v. Lal Behary
precedents.cited_proposition: approved Full Bench decision on proprietary element in shebaitship

anchor.surface_text: and again in Bhabatarini v. Ashalata 70 I.A. 57. The effect of the first two decisions, as the Privy Council pointed out in the last case, was to emphasize the proprietary element in the shebaiti right, and to show that though in some respects anomalous, it was an anomaly to be accepted as having been admitted into Hindu law from an early date. According to Hindu law, observed Lord Hobhouse in Gossamee Sree Greedharreejee v. Rumanlolljee Gossamee 16 I.A. 137, when the worship of a Thakoor has been founded, the shebaitship is held to be vested in the heirs of the founder, in default of evidence that he has disposed of it otherwise, or there has been some usage, course of dealing, or some circumstances to show a different mode of devolution.

precedents.cited_proposition: emphasize the proprietary element in the shebaiti right
precedents.cited_holding: Shebaitship is anomalous property accepted in Hindu law

precedents.citation: Gossamee Sree Greedharreejee v. Rumanlolljee Gossamee 16 I.A. 137

anchor.surface_text: According to Hindu law, observed Lord Hobhouse in Gossamee Sree Greedharreejee v. Rumanlolljee Gossamee 16 I.A. 137, when the worship of a Thakoor has been founded, the shebaitship is held to be vested in the heirs of the founder, in default of evidence that he has disposed of it otherwise, or there has been some usage, course of dealing, or some circumstances to show a different mode of devolution. Unless, therefore, the founder has disposed of the shebaitship in any particular manner - and this right of disposition is inherent in the founder - or except when usage or custom of a different nature is proved to exist, shebaitship like any other species of heritable property follows the line of inheritance from the founder.

precedents.case_name: Gossamee Sree Greedharreejee v. Rumanlolljee Gossamee
precedents.cited_proposition: shebaitship is held to be vested in the heirs of the founder
precedents.cited_holding: Shebaitship devolves on heirs of founder unless otherwise provided

precedents.citation: Anuragi Kuer v. Paramanand, A.I.R. 1939 Pat. 1

anchor.surface_text: After her death the shebaiti right would not pass to her stridhana heirs but would go to heirs of the last shebait Anuragi Kuer v. Paramanand, A.I.R. 1939 Pat. 1. Sub-section (3) of section 3, therefore, is of no assistance to Mr. Banerjees client.

precedents.cited_proposition: shebaiti right of widow reverts to heirs of the last male shebait, not her stridhana heirs
precedents.cited_holding: Widow's shebaitship does not pass to her heirs but to heirs of last male owner

precedents.citation: Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference may not be made to the decision Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1, upon which the learned appellate Judges of the High Court practically based their decision. The facts of that case stripped of unnecessary details are that one Arunachalam Chettiar who was a resident of Madras and owned considerable properties, moveable and immoveable, both within and outside British India, died leaving behind him two widows and the widow of a predeceased son.

precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act not applicable to trust properties or trusteeship without beneficial interest
precedents.cited_holding: Act applies only to properties beneficially owned, not trusteeship

anchor.surface_text: We think that a very proper view of the effect of this decision of the Federal Court has been taken by a Division Bench of the Madras High Court in P. Suryanarayanacharyulu v. P. Seshamma . There the question arose in connection with the rights associated with the office of archakatvam, which is a hereditary religious office and the holder or holders of it for the time being are beneficially entitled to enjoy the income of the endowed property. It was held that the principle laid down by the Federal Court in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1 has no application to a case relating to the office of archakatvam.

precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act applies to archakatvam office with beneficial interest; distinguishes Umayal Achi
precedents.cited_holding: Principle in Umayal Achi has no application to hereditary religious office with beneficial entitlement

precedents.citation: Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: Plausible and attractive is this line of reasoning, and it lends support to the view taken in Umayal Achi v. Lakshmi Achi 1945 F.C.R. 1 by Sir Varadachariar, where, referring to sub-clause (3) of Section 3, he observes - This provision will be appropriate enough in relation to private property where the womans estate is different from the interest taken by a male heir. But in respect of trusteeship or other similar office, the law makes no difference between the interest taken by a male heir and the interest taken by a female heir.

precedents.cited_proposition: Hindu womans estate distinction inapplicable to trusteeship or similar office
precedents.cited_holding: No difference in interest between male and female in trusteeship

anchor.surface_text: The exact legal position of a shebait may not be capable of precise definition but its implications are fairly well established. It is settled by the pronouncement of the Judicial Committee in Vidya Varuti v. Balusami 48 I.A. 302... shebaitship like any other species of heritable property follows the line of inheritance from the founder.

The result, therefore, is that, in our opinion, the appeal succeeds. The judgment and decree of both the courts below are set aside except the declaration of the right of residence of the plaintiff which was given by the trial court and not disturbed in appeal. In addition to that, it will be declared that the plaintiff is entitled to joint shebaitship with the defendant in respect

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that we are not at all impressed by the argument of the learned counsel that the words heirs of the said Mrityunjoy occurring in the document are to be construed as words not of inheritance but of grant. Such construction would be against the language and the whole tenor of the document.

The result, therefore, is that, in our opinion, the appeal succeeds. The judgment and decree of both the courts below are set aside except the declaration of the right of residence of the plaintiff which was given by the trial court and not disturbed in appeal. In addition to that, it will be declared that the plaintiff is entitled to joint shebaitship with the defendant in respect
